abstract.p: Over the last 50 years, the number of patients with mycotic infections has gradually increased. Amphotericin-B is a gold-standard drug used in serious systemic fungal infections. However, limited solubility and permeability are challenging issues associated with Amphotericin-B. Chemical modification is one of the ways to get its broader applicability and improved physicochemical properties. The review article provides a comprehensive overview of the chemical modification approach for investigating the mechanism of action, biological activity, bioavailability, and toxicity of Amphotericin B. Further, several drug delivery approaches have also been utilized to provide better therapeutic outcomes. This gives an overview of chemical approaches for exploring various factors associated with Amphotericin B and information on its drug delivery approaches for improved biopharmaceutical outcomes.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The fungi belonging to the eukaryotic kingdom possess heterotrophic nature [1]. They contain chitin in the cell wall, and their cell membranes are made up of sterols, glycerophospholipids, and sphingolipids [2]. Over the last 50 years, the number of patients with mycotic infections has been increasing as they are affected by many species of fungi like Aspergillus, Candida, Cryptococcus, and Pneumocystis [3]. Mycotic infections are unignorable causes of lethality in immune-deficient persons. The early detection of systemic mycotic infections in immune-compromised persons is still challenging due to the scarcity of sensitive diagnostic techniques [4]. In the current scenario, the only drug available in the market to cure these fungal infections at up to best is Amphotericin B (AmB) because it is resistant free and a safer candidate for severe fungal infections that occur during organ transplantations, acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), hematological malignancy, etc. Still, the huge problem is the availability of its formulation in the intravenous (IV) dosage form, which is uneasy for administration. So it's a big challenge for the researchers to formulate this drug in the oral dosage form.

The applications of AmB in chemotherapy are limited because of high human toxicity and poor bioavailability [5]. AmB generally produces toxicity to the ergosterol-contain-ing fungal cell membrane, but it also interacts to some extent with the cholesterol-containing mammalian cell memb-

rane, and as a result, of this, it produces toxicity to mammalian cells also [6]. AmB shows side effects including pyrexia, nausea, emesis, headache, low BP, allergic symptoms, and renal and hepatotoxicity [7]. Amphotericin-B is a BCS class IV drug because of poor solubility and permeability and comes under polyene macrolides. Amphotericin B was generated by Streptomyces nodosus in 1955 is the essential member of macrolides [8, 9]. Its chemical aspects are still being explored because of its complex structure and a scarcity of appropriate synthetic techniques [8].

Amphotericin B has applications in mycotic plant infections too. And they are also used as antiviral, antineoplastic [10-14], anti-leishmanial, against inflammation, against AIDS-related mycotic infections [15], against nosocomial fungal infections [16, 17], against Alzheimer's, Creutzfeldt-Jakob, and human immune deficiency viral infections [18, 19]. It is also employed against protozoal infections [20].

sec.title: Mechanism of Action of AmB
sec.p: The other antifungal drugs such as polyenes (damage mycotic membranes), azoles (suppress ergosterol biosynthesis), & echinocandins (impede the formation of cell wall - glucan) are covered under three key categories of drugs with varied modes of action-still, all having limitations including toxicity, narrow spectrum, drug-drug interactions, and cost-ineffective. Amphotericin B binds to ergosterol, the leading constituent of the mycotic cell membrane [21]. Its function is revealed by an ion channel complex, which AmB and sterol compile into molecular assemblages. The renowned “barrel-stave aggregation model,” which consisted of around eight pairs of AmB/sterol, was introduced in the 1970s. AmB participates with sterols in phospholipid membranes to construct barrel-stave openings. The AmB molecules are aligned in a quasi-parallel orientation. Their polyhydroxy part points inward to set up the pore sheathing, and their lipophilic heptaene segment directs outward to link with the membrane interior (Fig. 1) [22-24].

sec.p: Yet, recent research has revealed that AmB's sterol-independent pores play a crucial role in its functions. The ion channel complex formation mechanism is vital for determining the bimolecular interactions between AmB-AmB and AmB-lipids [9]. The specifics of amphotericin B's mechanism of action remain a mystery after five decades of intensive study. Amphotericin B is believed to induce electrolyte and small molecule leakage from exposed cells. Yet, it must be confirmed if electrolyte discharge is the leading cause of Amphotericin-B induced cell death. The methods of mechanistic inquiry have been used in recent attempts [12, 13, 25]. AmB counteracts yeast in two ways: (i) ergosterol adhering dependent channel construction have needed for antifungal activity, or (ii) ergosterol adhering is a major mechanism of antifungal activity, with channel construction presenting as an auxiliary mechanism of action (Fig. 2) [26].

The UV/CD spectroscopic methods and molecular dynamics calculations could not explore the details of the ion-permeable channel's molecular architecture. The molecular assemblage of AmB-sterol is assumed to reach dissociation/association equilibrium, arising in an exchange between the channel's conducting and non-conducting domains, rendering spectroscopic analysis of the active assemblage complicated. As an outcome, if dimers rather than monomers take part in this mechanism, the equilibrium should switch to the associated state, permitting NMR measurements to be recorded (Fig. 3) [9, 27].

Using solid-state NMR techniques, Oishi, T., and Murata, M. explored the molecular basis of AmB-ergosterol complexes in hydrated PC bilayers, a more physiologically pertinent system than freeze-dried or frozen membrane preparations [28].

sec.title: Chemistry Point of View of Amphotericin-B
sec.p: The Amphotericin-B possesses a large, highly complex structure (Fig. 4). Its scaffolding encompasses polyketide, which is hooked up to a mycosamine sugar. The hydrophobic polyene subunit is affixed to the hydrophilic polyol segment of the molecule. That’s why it is classified as a polyene macrolide. It is embodied up of a 38-membered macrolactone nucleus glycosylated at C-19 hydroxyl position to the mycosamine [29]. The C-7 to C-10 polyol sites part of amphotericin B structure significantly influence the antifungal activity [30, 31]. The (+)-charged amine is necessary for biological activity & the polyene component is necessary for activity according to the pharmacophore of the AmB molecule (Fig. 4). The preference for ergosterol over cholesterol is reduced when the carboxyl group is negatively charged; nevertheless, N-aminoacylation improves selectivity. The absolute configuration of Amphotericin B was confirmed in 1970 using a single-crystal analysis of the N-iodoacetyl derivative of AmB [8, 21].

sec.p: The C35-hydroxyl unit is speculated to be necessary for creating and stabilizing dimeric ion channels via hydrogen bonding [34]. AmB is a cyclic amphiphile composed of two long chains, a poly hydroxy, which is hydrophilic, and a hydrophobic polyene of seven double bond links conjugated with E geometry.

Amphotericin B has the name Amphotericin B because of its amphoteric behavior [35]. AmB binds membrane-encapsulated ergosterol, the amplest sterol in yeast cells, in a form that necessitates the presence of the mycosamine appendage at C19, according to Gray, et al. Amphoterono- lide B (Fig. 6) is formed when the mycosamine appendage is removed from AmB, and then it is unable to bind ergosterol, create ion channels, and shows no antimycotic effect [26]. The mycosamine appendage is indispensable for ergosterol and cholesterol-binding, although the three functional groups' respective roles at C2, C3, and C4 are anonymous [36].

Resat et al. tell that the drug's selective toxicity is affected by amino sugar's relative orientation to the macrolide unit [12, 13, 32]. Fluorination is a reliable alternative for more fitting derivatives with diminished toxicity because of medical aftereffects [11]. A series of modified AmB derivatives, such as Amphotericin B methyl ester (AME) and numerous amide, N-alkyl, and N-acyl derivatives, have been developed to achieve more effective and less toxic therapeutics [37, 38]. The polyamine conjugates of AmB possess the power to boost potency since the membrane is considered AmB's primary goal [16, 17]. Burke et al. envisaged that the C2' hydroxyl group on the mycosamine appendage is crucial for binding both sterols (ergosterol and cholesterol) using a commanding structural model [14]. The chemical alterations of AmB and the genetically engineered polyenes (at C16 carboxyl group or the amino group of mycosamine moiety) could emerge in unique derivatives with low toxicity and therapeutic efficacy [39]. The amphiphilic nature of AmB makes it weakly dissolved in most organic solvents and approximately insoluble in water under physiological conditions of pH values 6-7. It is administered through the intravenous (IV) route as a complex with sodium deoxycholate, which behaves as a dispersant, emerging in water-soluble micellar colloidal conglomerates with AmB [7]. The aggregates form of AmB is toxic to both mammalian and fungal cells, but the monomeric form is toxic only to fungal cells. The selective toxicity of AmB can be improved by the chemical modification on carboxyl and amine groups, respectively [40]. Day et al. inspected that in the presence of PLP (Vitamin), both AmB and nystatin are efficiently dissolved in water, reaping concentrations of greater than 100 mg/mL (the highest concentration evaluated) [41].
Amphotericin B has the problem of toxicity, poor bioavailability, uncertain information about its mechanism of action, etc. So, there are separate chemical modification approaches for all the issues.

sec.title: The Chemical Modification Approaches of Amphotericin-B
sec.p: This section comprises five approaches emphasizing mechanism of action, biological activity, bioavailability, toxicity, and drug carriers.

sec.title: Chemical Modification Approach for the Investigation of the Mechanism of Action of Amphotericin-B
sec.p: The covalently conjoined dimers of AmB synthesized through cross-linking their carboxylic acid were described by Yamaji et al. A dimer (Fig. 7) with a 1, 6-hexanediamine linkage showed powerful hemolytic action (EC50, 0.25 M), while its N-acetyl derivative caused substantial K+ ion leakage in phosphatidylcholine liposomes, despite the availability or unavailability of sterols, pointing that dimers might be used to decipher the structure of the Amphotericin B-induced ion channel assembly [9].
An AmB dimer with a carboxylic acid connection was prepared using a simple reaction arrangement displayed in (Scheme 1) [9].

Matsumori et al. reported AmB dimers with the channel-forming ability for investigation of bimolecular recognition of AmB/sterol [27]. The stable fluorinated derivative of AmB carrying a fluorine atom in the macrolide backbone was reported by Matsumori et al. It was produced by employing a Selectfluor (electrophilic fluorination reagent). The claimed derivative had hemolytic, K+ permeable, and antimycotic properties similar to AmB. Hence, predicted to be an appropriate means for NMR-based studies of the process of amphotericin B ion-channel creation. They also synthesized a conveniently accessible derivative 3 for NMR studies by employing the reductive amination to AmB along with a 19F-labeled molecule (p-fluorobenzaldehyde) at the amino group (For scheme, Please refer to article) [11].

Tsuchikawa et al. integrated chemical synthesis through cross-coupling reactions & macrolactonization along with degeneration of a natural product to produce a fluorinated Amphotericin B (AmB) derivative, 28-19F-AmB methyl ester, tagged at the polyene part. The fluorinated derivative 3, which has an antimycotic activity identical to AmB, is envisioned to be a useful device for NMR-based studies of ion-channel creation mechanisms (For figure, Please refer to article) [37].

Palacios et al. described an approach that removes synthetic groups affixed to the macrolide scaffold and assesses the functional outcomes. It recommends that oxidation at C(41) is not essential for potent antimycotic activity, and channel creation is also not required for the same, contrary to the existing channel hypothesis. They eventually came up with a diverse degradative method that allows for the synthetic reversal of one or both of the two post polyketide synthase modifications critical for AmB channel self-aggregation (Scheme 2) [42].

Szpilman et al. reported the synthesis of 35-deoxy AME (Fig. 9) utilizing a new approach for linking mycosamine to the aglycone. The (-OH) on C35 is important in the double-barrel construct's stability. This article addresses a method for completing the whole synthesis of AmB analogues, including glycosidation & subsequent exploration processes. It describes its use in the manufacture of 35-deoxy AME in particular. It also presents data that experimentally affirms the significance of (-OH) at C35 in its antimycotic activity & capacity to trigger electrolyte discharge in liposomes for the first time [24].

For investigating the interaction among AmB & ergosterol or cholesterol, Murata et al. synthesized 13C & 19F-tagged covalent conjugates and used solid-state NMR studies. They calculated the gap between the fluorine atom and its most adjacent carbon in the heptaene part to be less than 8.6 by employing rotor-synchronous double-resonance studies such as rotational echo double resonance (REDOR) and RDX, showing that the B ring of ergosterol gets adjacent to the AmB polyene portion. In contrast to the popular notion in which ergosterol is injected into AmB molecules, a conformational inspection of the AmB-erg conjugate adopting NMR-derived constraints revealed that erg molecules besiege the AmB assemblage. Employing 13C and 19F-tagged AmBs in a dimyristoyl phosphatidylcholine (DMPC) membrane without sterols, the bimolecular inte- raction between AmB and AmB was investigated. The REDOR experiments identified 13C-19F dipolar interac- tions acquired from both head-to-head & head-to-tail orientations and identified AmB interactions with the phos- pholipid's acyl chains. They synthesized labeled compounds and chemically conjugated them to stabilize the AmB-sterol interaction (For scheme, please refer to article). AmB was electrophilically labeled with a fluorine atom at C14 to produce fluorine-labeled AmB (For scheme, please refer to article). By nourishing the microbes 3-13C-propionic acid, 13C was integrated into C39, C40, & C41, resulting in 13C-labeled AmB at both terminal locations (For scheme, please refer to article). As given in the schematic, the chemical synthesis of the polyene/tail region of AmB was brought out further to attain 13C and 19F-tagged AmB at the polyene portion (For scheme, please refer to article) [22].

Szpilman et al. reported (a) The molecular editing employed for the interpretation of the AmB function and (b) A standard approach for the synthesis of AmB and its prepared analogues, which depends on an economic gram-scale synthesis of distinct amphotericin B subunits, (c) A innovative approach for conjoining the mycosamine to the aglycone, (d) Inspection of the antimycotic activity & efflux causing capability of AmB analogue contributed new keys to the function of the 35-hydroxy group. This study described the synthetic production of 35-deoxy AME in detail and biophysical experiments that indicated the influence of the C35-hydroxy group on bioactivity. Alter- native pathways to the C1-C13 & C33-C37 portions were also revealed (For schemes, please refer to the article) [34].

Palacios et al. reported a dominant cluster of functional groups lacking probes that exposed ion channel anatomy and Amphotericin B antifungal activity. In contradiction to the two dominant models, polar interactions between mycosamine & carboxylic acid auxiliaries on adjacent Amphotericin B molecules are not necessary for ion channel development or binding to phospholipid bilayers. The mycosamine sugar is also essential for developing a direct binding affinity among amphotericin B & ergosterol, which supports a hitherto unproven third theory. The same may be said of cholesterol. Ion channel and antifungal actions are likewise fully eliminated when this appendage is synthetically deleted. It means that both channel creation and yeast cell death require a mycosamine arbitrated straight binding relationship between amphotericin B & ergosterol [23].

Wilcock et al. reported changing the electronic nature of the reagents to tune site selectivity. They were able to modify one of the numerous hydroxyl groups connected to the ion channel creating the natural substance amphotericin B with these breakthroughs. As a result, electronic tuning of reagents is a viable technique for identifying and optimizing site-specific functionalization reactions [36].

AmB's high fungicidal activity is not dependent on channel formation, according to Gray et al. This is confirmed by preparing a functional group lacking a derivative of this natural product via iterative cross-coupling. AmB, on the other hand, destroyed yeast by sticking to ergosterol, a lipid essential for abounding facets of yeast cell function [26].

Umegawa et al. employed 13C{19F} 19F-REDOR investigations using C14-tagged AmB & biosynthetically 13C-tagged ergosterol to decode the style of molecular interactions between AmB & ergosterol in aquated phos- pholipid bilayers, implying that each “head-to-head” & “head-to-tail” AmB orientations ensue for ergosterol [28].

The international patent WO 2014/059436 Al reported the site-selective functionalization of Amphotericin B was achieved merely by altering the reagents' electronic nature. One of many hydroxyl groups added to the ion channel-creating natural product amphotericin B was modified in various ways. The method comprises the steps of selecting, based on its electron richness, a functionalizing reagent for reaction with at least one potential site for functionalization of a substrate molecule having a plurality of potential sites for functionalization; and reacting the functionalizing reagent with at least one of potential sites for functiona- lization in a reaction represented by S+R(D)→S(D) wherein S represents the substrate molecule having a plurality of potential sites for functionalization; R(D) represents the functionalizing reagent comprising a functional group [43].

“The alteration of functional groups that modify the conductance of the AmB ion channel was described by Davis et al. The C3-OH group was synthesized & the resultant compound, C3deoxyAmB (C3deOAmB), was analyzed utilizing multidimensional NMR measure- ments & single ion channel electrophysiological recordings to test the idea. Although C3deOAmB channels have the unchanged macrocycle structure as AmB & can create transmembrane ion channels, their conductance is three times lower than AmB channels. As a result, the C3-hydroxyl group performs a crucial character in AmB ion channel conductance, & synthetic changes at this point may enable more channel function tailoring” [44, 45].

“To deeply learn the mechanism of antimycotic activity, Yamamoto et al. used ssNMR to study the molecular orientation of AmB. The NMR isotope-labeled AME, d3-AME, and its fluorinated or 13C-labeled derivatives were synthesized. All AmB derivatives had identical membrane-disrupting capabilities and UV spectra in phospholipid liposomes, implying that their molecular assemblages in membranes are quite comparable to those of AmB. Accor- ding to solid-state 2H NMR observations of d3-AME in a hydrated membrane, the AME molecule's mobility depends on concentration and temperature. AME got sufficiently mobilized to witness motional averaging of quadrupole coupling at a 1:5:45 AME:Erg:dimyristoyl-phosphatidyl- choline ratio. They observed that the molecular axis of AME is mainly parallel to the typical lipid bilayer, counting on the average rotational effect of 19F chemical shift anisotropy, 2H quadrupolar splitting, and 13C-19F dipolar coupling of 14-F-AMEs.This finding backs with the barrel-stave model of AmB molecule assembly in membranes (For schemes, please refer to article)” [46].

sec.title: Chemical Modification Approach for the Investigation of Biological Activity Produced by Amphotericin-B
sec.p: Schaffner and co-patentor Mechlinski patented derivatives of amphoteric polyene macrolide antibiotics, comprising (a) the (-CH3), (-C2H5), or (-C3H7), ester created through the esterification of the (-COOH), & (b) salts of these esters formed with the (-NH2) group for the study of biological activity of Amphotericin B. The derivatives of (a) & (b) had effective antifungal activity compared to the parent antibiotics. The reagents like CH2N2, C2H4N2 & C3H6N2 are more efficacious & astonishingly choosy for polyene antibiotics, specifically preventing unwanted reactions for esterification. The acid salts (b) of Schaffner et al., produced by suitable acids, e.g., hydrochlorides, showed great aqueous dissolution that is usually not shown by parent drug & also have particular benefit in retaining the strong activity [47].

sec.p: To more appropriately determine the affiliation among the amino-sugar orientation and pharmacological action, Matsumori and his co-workers developed rigid compounds having bridged (-NH2) & (-COOH) groups along with varied alkyl chains. K+ influx assays throughout the lipid bilayer membrane displayed that ergosterol selectivity varied significantly amid compounds, indicating that some lost activity while others had a stronger ergosterol preference than AmB. Because of the short bridge, the amino-sugar moiety of one derivative comes close to C41, whereas those of others point outward, according to the Monte Carlo conformational study of selected derivatives pertaining to NOE determined distances. These findings explain AmB-sterol interactions, in which H-bonding between AmB's 2'-OH and ergosterol's 3'-OH plays a key role (For schemes, please refer to article) [13].

Through a twofold reductive alkylation of the mycosamine, Paquet and his co-worker Carreira generated novel derivatives of Amphotericin B (AmB). These AmB derivatives outperformed the wild-type Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain in antifungal activity, exclusively anti to AmB resistant Candida albicans strain. Furthermore, these derivatives had considerably lower hemotoxicity than AmB, making them suitable therapeutic candidates. And they identified that alkylation of the mycosamine moiety of AmB with 2-aminopropylene (Fig. 10) groups contributes to congeners with considerably augmented antimycotic activity also to an AmB-resistant strain. This noted increment in bio-activity allowed speedy access to C-16 carboxylate compounds with diminished hemotoxicity and retained high efficacy. Mini- mal inhibitory concentration (MIC) against S. cerevisiae for AmB was 0.30 µM, and for bis (aminopropylene) derivative was 0.020 µM [48].

Matsumori and his co-worker Sawada and Michio Murata, to decipher more about the active conformation of AmB, developed a fresh intramolecular-bridged derivative, in which a linker attached to a hydrophilic glycine part. The derivative's ion-channel action is nearly identical to that of the AmB & the previously reported derivative. One deriva- tive's antifungal activity improves surprisingly compared to the other, probably because the linker's increased hydro- philicity improves penetrability through the fungal cell wall. The ssNMR method was applied to confirm the active framework of AmB. (For scheme, please refer to article) [12].

Zumbuehl et al. proposed “a novel linker technique relied on 2-fold reductive amination of a dialdehyde to the amine of the AmB, also a comparison of the biological activity of conjugates to AmB. They also disclosed synthesizing the extra conjugates employing a piperazine linker & a related conjugation strategy involving a 4-carboxy- piperidinyl linker.” (For scheme, please refer to article) [49].

Paquet et al. mentioned novel cationic AmB deri- vatives obtained by modifying amine & carboxyl moiety of AmB, emphasizing polyamine derivatives with two 3-aminopropyl chains on the mycosamine. For the evaluation of bio-activity, the EH50 values were used. The net charge on the AmB favored the monomeric form by hindering self-association with reduced toxicity. The cationic AmB derivative increases essential H-bond ability following the proposed ion channel model. The presence of polar functional groups may give rise to the formation of water-soluble salts. The polyamines efficiently interact with negatively charged phospholipids in the biological memb- rane (For all schemes, please refer to the article) [16].

The international patent WO 2015/164289 Al et al. reported the constitutions & approaches for treating mycotic infections, including compounds containing a chemotaxis receptor-ligand moiety and a polyene antifungal agent moiety. Specifically, the compounds containing a polyene antifungal agent and a formyl peptide receptor ligand can be used to treat fungal infections caused by a fungus of the genus Aspergillus or Candida [50].

The international patent WO 2015/168568 Al disclosed the derivatives mainly [C16 ureas, amides, & carbamates (Formula I)], [C3'-substituted C16 ureas, amides, & carbamates (Formula II)], [C16 acyls (Formula III)], [C2'epi-C16 ureas, amides, & carbamates (Formula IV)], and [C16 oxazolidinone derivatives (Formula V)] of AmB with better therapeutic index compared to parent AmB [51].

These compounds, salts, & compositions helped inhibit fungal growth (For scheme, Please refer to article) [55].

Such compounds, salts, and compositions are useful for inhibiting fungal growth (For all formulae, please refer to patent) [56].

The international patent WO 2014/165676 Al reported the Amphotericin-B (AmB) derivative with better therapeutic effect than AmB, pharmaceutical preparations containing it, methods of its preparation & its use in preventing the proliferation of yeast or fungus. The Amphotericin-B derivative, C2'deOAmB (For figure, Please refer to article), doesn’t have the hydroxyl group at the 2' position on mycosamine, so it differs from the parent compound. This modified derivative had retained the capability to bind ergosterol and stop yeast growth with reduced toxicity to human cells by not binding to cholesterol [14].

sec.title: The Chemical Modification Approach of Amphotericin B for Bioavailability Improvement
sec.p: Greatly water dissolving N-alkylguanidine/N-acylurea bis-adduct of AmB was obtained by reaction of Amphotericin B in DMF with bis(dimethylamino propyl)carbodiimide as disclosed by Adediran et al. Its water absorption spectra had shown good monomerization & antimycotic activity against Candida albicans with reference AmB was comparable. It was less pro-inflammatory because of less effective in engaging TLR4. They also attempted coupling spermine to carboxylic acid by employing carbodiimide chemistry. That adduct had equipotent antifungal action against Candida albicans, and it also triggered toll-like receptor-2 (TLR2) and TLR4-driven NF-κB responses in reporter gene assays identical to AmB molecule (For schemes, please refer to the article) [33].

Nicolaou et al. reported the series of protected derivatives of AmB. They have shown that one compound is converted to fragments by degradation through ozonolysis. They also performed the degradation of compounds to heptanones using an exclusive oxidative deglycosylation technique depending on radical bromination. The heptanones were then stereospecifically reduced to amphoteronolide B derivatives using sodium borohydride. Using Nakanishi's CD technique, they validated the R form of the C-19 (-OH) group. They accessed the aglycon of AmB, amphoteronolide B through desilylation & (-CH3) ester hydrolysis. They got the diacetonide methyl ester derivative as a mixture of two isomers in 66% overall yield by treating acetamide methyl ester derivative with MeOH: Me2C(OMe)2 (3:1) under acid catalysis (CSA) at 25°C from Amphotericin B. The excellent solubility characteristics exhibited by this derivative and compounds developed from it in popular organic solvents, and it acted chromatographically & spectroscopically generally [57].

sec.p: The strategies for synthesizing immense purity alkyl esters of polyene macrolide antibiotics have been patented by Mohan and his co-worker Somerville; the reaction media, polyene antibiotics react with an aldehyde to constitute a soluble Schiff base. The alkyl ester of the polyene macrolide antibiotic is then generated as a Schiff base derivative by alkylating the solution in the presence of a hindered tertiary amine as an acid acceptor. The Schiff base derivative is converted to the desired alkyl ester of the polyene macrolide antibiotic by contacting it with water, which is recovered from the reaction media. This invention concerns new Schiff base intermediates of amphoteric polyene macrolides, their transformation to alkyl esters, & their use in synthesizing polyene macrolide esters & water dissolving salts correspondingly [10].

The two novel categories of amide derivatives of polyene macrolide with greater water solubility than native AmB & Amphotericin-B methyl ester (AME) beneficial towards mycotic infections had been patented by Chang et al. having international patent number WO 01/91758 Al. [32] One class affords polyene macrolide amide derivatives as per the structural formula 1 and the second class affords polyene macrolide amide derivatives as per the structural formula 2. The subsequent exploration of the formulae (I) and (II) in which N-R1-C(O) is a polyene macrolide backbone derived from AmB to structures (Ia) and (IIa), respectively (For detailed information, please refer to patent) [32].

Elgart et al. announced the alteration in the distri- bution of AmB when conjugated to AG in correspondence to the molecular weight of the conjugated polysaccharide. When conjugated to H-Mw AG, poorly water dissolving AmB with comprehensive disposition and high clearance converted into greatly dissolving AmB with small Vd and deficient clearance. This is due to the high molecular weight of the conjugate limiting its permeability and resulting in a greater concentration of AmB & vice versa with low molecular weight conjugate. Hence conjugation of AmB with AG yielded a novel entity with altered pharmacokinetic characteristics [58]. Day et al. disclosed the application of pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) for achieving excellent solubilization of AmB [41].

Abeer et al. found that Amphotericin-B can form non-covalent complexes with Poly(α-glutamic acid). Com- pared to the parent molecule, this combination exhibited stability and lower toxicity in human RBC & KB cells. At concentrations of 50 and 200 g/mL of AmB, the cell viability was stable. This combination forms durable water dissolving & non-covalent complex with AmB to treat Leishmaniasis [59].

The international patent WO 2013/186384 Al reported the semisynthetic N-substituted derivatives of AmB and their aqueous salts as well as pharmaceutical preparations and also disclosed the products for plant & building treatments constituting these derivatives and their application as antimycotic agents according to the following formula I (For detailed information, please refer to the patent) [60].

V. V. Belakhov et al. disclosed the chemical modi- fication of Amphotericin B with dialkyl(diaryl)-phosphites through the Atherton-Todd reaction and also studied toxicity and anti-mycotic activity of the synthesized derivatives. The introduction of the phosphoryl group significantly increased the solubility of prepared derivatives. The dialkyl-(diaryl) amidophosphonate derivatives I-V were prepared by reacting AmB & dialkyl(diaryl)-phosphites (Please refer to the article for the scheme) [19].

Antillon et al. reported the novel L-histidine methyl ester of Amphotericin B (A21) derivative with improved selectivity. It reduced dimerization in solution, and pre-clinical studies suggest it is similarly effective as the AmB. It has a higher water solubility than AmB because it is solubilized at 50 mMol while AmB at μMol range (For the synthesis of A21 derivative, Please refer to article) [20].

The synthesis of a novel series of AmB conjugates with benzoxaboroles was reported by Tevyashova et al. The antifungal activity of conjugates was identical to that of native AmB when tested adopting the broth microdilution method on yeast (Candida albicans and Cryptococcus humicolus) & filamentous fungus (Aspergillus niger and Fusarium oxysporum). The di-modified conjugate 2-(N, N dimethylamino)ethylamide of 3-N-[3-(1-hydroxy-1,3-dihydrobenzo [c][1,2]oxaborol-7-yl)propanoyl] AmB confirmed the optimum combination of antimycotic efficacy, toxicity, and hemolysis. To enhance the solubility of 3′-N-substituted derivatives of AmB, they transformed compounds 3, 6, and 7 into the corresponding C16-2-(N, N-dimethylamino) ethylamides (DMAE-amides). The water solubility of C-16-DMAE-amides was excellent (For scheme, Please refer to article) [39].

Thanki et al. disclosed the AmB-lipid conjugate [AmB-oleyl conjugate (AmB-OA)] that enhances gastric stability (stable at stomach pH) & permeability (greater penetration through Caco-2 monolayer) for increasing bioavailability. This conjugate was identical to the parent AmB. This conjugate also interacts with Saccharomyces cerevisiae internal membranes, but AmB interacts only with the plasma membrane. The in-vivo PK studies showed that AmB-OA had a 3.13-fold increase in Cmax and a 4.88-fold rise in AUCTot compared to AmB [61].

Zhang et al. reported the novel AmB derivatives with greater therapeutic effect, diminished toxicity, and aqueous solubility. They checked nine N-substituted AmB derivatives for antimycotic activity by employing the broth dilution method and hemolytic toxicity using defibrinated sheep blood. The desired molecule, NH2-(AEEA)5-AmB (DMR 005; AEEA is 8-amino-3,6- dioxaoctanoic acid), was obtained after screening derivatives against two reference Candida albicans strains. So DMR005 showed good aqueous solubility, reduced toxicity, and retained antimycotic efficacy (For synthetic scheme, please refer to article) [62].

Tevyashova et al. synthesized the C16-modified AmB derivatives (Scheme 3). Out of all these derivatives, amphamide derivative showed drug-like properties, enhanced efficiency, improved safety, and more potency than AmB. The amphamide had shown lower acute toxicity and higher antifungal efficiency in the model of mice candidosis sepsis compared to AmB after performing electrophysiological and pharmacological studies. And it occurred possibly due to lower self-aggregation. And it has shown more excellent solubility [63].

And this azomethine was reacted with cyanoborohydride by reductive amination to furnish AmB derivatives (For scheme, please refer to article) [15].

Some of the compounds are C16 urea derivatives of AmB, while others are C3, C5, C8, C9, C11, C13, or C15 deoxy derivatives of AmB, as well as C3' or C4' alterations of AmB's mycosamine appendage. It also included infor- mation on how to make AmB derivatives of the invention, pharmaceutical compositions using AmB derivatives of the invention, and ways to use AmB derivatives of the invention (For methods, please refer to patent) [65].

Some of the derivatives are C16 urea derivatives and C16 carbamate of AmB. Also provided are the methods of making the AmB derivatives (For methods, please refer to patent) [66].

The international patent WO 2016/112243Al reported the urea compounds of AmB with enhanced efficacy and diminished toxicity compared to AmB and useful against mycotic infections. The urea derivatives of AmB can be obtained according to formula I, where R represents methyl, ethyl, propyl, or isopropyl; R' represents methyl, ethyl, propyl, or isopropyl; else, R and R’ can be taken together attaching to the nitrogen atom, represent a radical of a cyclic secondary amine. It also provided the methods for making the urea derivatives of AmB [67].

sec.title: The Chemical Modification Approach of Amphotericin-B with Conjugated Drug Carriers
sec.p: Polyethylene glycol is a linear amphiphilic polymer accessed by condensing ethylene oxide monomer with the general formula HO (CH2-CH2O) nH. It does not possess biodegradability, toxicity, and immunogenicity. It is employed in protein and small molecule modification. The attachment site for PEG in the Amphotericin-B molecule is the amine part. Conover C. D. et al. reported the two methods for PEG conjugation through the controlled release of amino groups. Of these two methods, the 1, 6-benzyl elimination system is more common (For more detail, please refer to the article) [70, 71].

“For the enhancement in the therapeutic efficacy of AmB, the polymeric carriers like polysaccharides, PEG, poly (ethylene glycol)-β-poly (L-lysine) can be attached with conjugates. The rate of release of AmB is controlled by the pH of the environment and the replacement of the benzene ring connected to the polymeric carrier” (acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of imine linkage) [72].

Larch arabinogalactans (AG) are employed as an attractive potential drug carrier due to their excellent aqueous solubility, biocompatibility, biodegradability, and flexibility of drug conjugation [58]. Polymer is not distributed systemically throughout the body, so it possesses the ability to reduce drug toxicity. In two ways, the diminished solubility of drugs can be enhanced by covalent conjugation or non-covalent association. Generally, covalent complexes are preferred to avoid chemical modification [59]. Amphotericin-B is available as Fungizone, Amphocin, Abelcet, and Ambisome with drug carriers [14].

The C-H activated one-step oligomerization technology, developed by changing the molar ratio between two co-monomers, could extend oligomer libraries. As a result, the chasm between conjugated polymers and tiny molecules may be bridged [73]. TPE-DPP4 and BP-DPP4 are two novel diketopyrrolopyrrolopyrrol (DPP) based π-conjugated oligomers that were easily synthesized using a ligand-free Pd-catalyzed sequential activation of the C-H bond in two steps with good yields starting from simple building blocks for exploring sustainable chemistry for renewable energy [74].

Nanotechnology plays a crucial role in the formation of drug delivery carriers for improvement in efficacy, lowering toxicity, and increasing the biocompatibility of drugs. The lipid-based nanocarriers are more in trend for AmB therapy as fungizone. Liposomal formulation (AmBisome) can diminish the nephrotoxicity associated with AmB. The prodrug technique of drug-lipid conjugates is used to tailor the physicochemical properties of the drug, which results in the improvement of GI permeability, gastric stability, and ultimately, poor bioavailability of drugs [61].

Sedlak et al. reported the preparation and characte- rization of “AmB-star polyethylene glycol (AmB-sPEG) conjugate” of AmB having a molecular weight of 25,160 with target-specific characteristics. It also possesses a β-D-glucopyranoside molecular switch sensitive to β-gluco- sidases, which is responsible for the release of AmB, and it was confirmed in vitro by spectrophotometry and HPLC (For schemes, please refer to article) [72].

Halperin et al. disclosed the two new PEG amide conjugates of amphotericin B, AB1, and AM2 with stable attributes. These conjugates showed antimycotic activity against a broad range of clinical fungal isolates, as confirmed by in vivo studies in a mouse model of systemic candidiasis. These can be formulated in two or three synthetic steps only. These possess diminished toxicity and aqueous solubility up to 5000-fold greater than AmB. In solubility studies, AB1 showed greater than 5000 more solubilities than AmB, and AM2 showed greater than 700 more solubilities than AmB. It indicates that the methyl-ester group that replaced AmB's carboxyl group in AM2 causes it to be more inadequate water-soluble than AB1. (For schemes, tables, and figures, please refer to the article) [7].

sec.title: Drug Delivery Approaches of Amphotericin-B
sec.p: This section comprises fourteen approaches applicable in the delivery of Amphotericin B.

sec.title: Solid Lipid Nano-particles (SLNs)
sec.p: Manisha and her co-worker attained the excellent oral bioavailability and diminished toxicity of AmB by forming SLNs filled with AmB. These SLNs maintained the AmB in its monomeric form for ergosterol binding because its dimeric form binds with cholesterol, which is responsible for toxicity enhancement. A sonication-aided nanoprecipitation technique developed these particles [77]. Butani and a co-worker had also prepared the SLN of Amphotericin B [78].

sec.title: PLGA-PEG Nanoparticles
sec.p: For the delivery of monomeric AmB, Mahasen et al. prepared the nanoparticle formulation containing a poly (lactide-co-glycolide)-poly (ethylene glycol) (PLGA-PEG) co-polymer filled with AmB & glycyrrhizic acid as an absorption promoter. This formulation showed excellent antimycotic activity in in-vitro studies against Candida albicans and improved bioavailability than AmB in pharmacokinetic evaluation. Kumar et al. reported this formulation against Leishmania donovani in hamsters with more significant inhibition than the free AmB group [79, 80]. Bushra T. AL-Quadeib et al. also reported the PLGA-PEG co-polymer as a drug delivery agent for nano-formulation of Amphotericin B [81].

sec.title: Nanostructured Lipid Carriers
sec.p: Janet et al. reported the preparation of nanostructured lipid carriers (NLC) for improvement in oral bioavailability of AmB & reduction in toxicity through delivery in monomeric form. It comprises a blend of solid lipids & lipidic oils and an additional chitosan coating for mucoadhesion to enhance lymphatic delivery [82]. Bavani Subramaniam and a co-worker also reported the nanostructured lipid carrier (NLC) for AmB delivery [83].

sec.title: Polymeric Micelles
sec.p: Ying et al. reported a micellar formulation having self-assembling property for oral delivery of AmB. This formulation was prepared by the thin-film method by loading AmB in a micellar system of lecithin-based mixed polymers. It enhances the solubility of AmB, improves oral bioavailability, and diminishes toxicity than fungizone [84]. Wang et al. also reported the polymeric micelles for AmB delivery [85].

sec.title: Oil in Water Micro Emulsion
sec.p: Acarilia et al. reported the oil in water (O/W) micro emulsion of AmB formulation to enhance solubility and reduce toxicity compared to the parent drug. This formulation consists of a blend of tween 80 & span 80, having an HLB value of 13, and capryol PGMC as an oil phase composition [86].

sec.title: Pickering Emulsion
sec.p: Pickering emulsion is an emulsion with solid particles instead of surfactants for internal phase stabilization. Richter et al. prepared the Pickering emulsion filled with AmB. The cashew tree gum was grafted with polylactide nanoparticles used to stabilize this formulation. It showed excellent incorporation efficiency without excess aggregation [87].

sec.title: Chitosan and Porphyrin Polymeric Nanocarrier
sec.p: Bhatia et al. reported the biodegradable polymeric nanocarrier made up of oppositely charged chitosan and porphyrin, representing a polyelectrolyte complex to load AmB. This complex possesses diminished degradation in SGF and releases AmB than parent AmB confirmed by stability studies. An in vitro study showed that this formulation has more antifungal activity than free AmB as measured by the IC50 method. And it also showed less hemolytic toxicity compared to free AmB, confirmed by in vitro study [88].

sec.title: Co-polymer
sec.p: Mohamed and a co-worker prepared the formulation of a pH-sensitive co-polymer containing tragacanth and acrylic acid employing γ-irradiation. It protects the drug in a simulated gastric fluid having acidic pH and releases it in an alkaline environment. The efficacy of (Trag/Aac)-AmB was similar to free AmB. This formulation showed less renal damage than free AmB [89]. Kingo Banshoya and co-authors have also reported the co-polymer of Amphotericin-B with styrene-maleic acid (For figure, Please refer to article) [90].

sec.title: Solid-self Nano Emulsifying Drug Delivery System (S-SNEDDS)
sec.p: Singh et al. used spray-dried covalently inter-connected EDTA-chitosan (micro-particles) to develop a new solid-Self Nano Emulsifying Drug delivery system for the oral formulation of AmB. In an aqueous condition, this formulation displayed the capability of self nano emulsification to generate a stable formulation [91].

sec.title: Cubosomes
sec.p: Yang et al. reported a cubosomal formulation for the delivery of AmB to overcome the problem of poor bioavailability & prepared by SolEmuls technology. It showed no nephrotoxicity at 10-20 mg/kg doses in a small animal model. The oral bioavailability of cubosome formulation increased by 285% compared to Fungizone, as shown in pharmacokinetic results (See article for results) [92].

sec.title: Carbon Nanotubes
sec.p: Prajapati et al. disclosed the carbon nanotubes to develop an oral formulation of AmB, which is attached to AmB covalently. This formulation showed potent inhibition against the parasite in in-vivo studies [93]. Hang Sun and co-authors have reported the conjugate of Amphotericin-B with carbon nanotubes [94].

sec.title: GCPQ Nanoparticles
sec.p: Serrano et al. reported the quaternary ammonium palmitoyl glycol chitosan (GCPQ) nanoparticles encapsulating AmB to improve oral bioavailability along with site-specificity and non-toxicity. This formulation showed identical efficacy to the parent drug and improved dissolution in simulated GIF than AmB [95].

sec.title: Cochleates
sec.p: Zarif et al. reported the application of cochleate for AmB delivery against Candida infections. “The cochleate is made up of solid lipid bilayers arranged in rolled-up sheets composed of phospholipid-cation precipitates, majorly phosphatidylserine and calcium respectively”. It was prepared by the hydrogel method, protects AmB in GIT from degradation, and showed stability, site-specificity, and non-hemotoxicity confirmed by in-vitro evaluation [96, 97].

sec.title: Self-emulsifying Drug Delivery System (SEDDS)
sec.p: Wasan et al. disclosed a self-emulsifying drug delivery system to enhance the bioavailability, reduce toxicity, stability, and anti-Leishmanial activity of AmB. It is a lipid-based formulation administered by oral route [98-101].

sec.p: Although molecular acidity is one of the essential physicochemical parameters of a molecular system, accurate computation and prediction remains a challenge in the literature. Density functional reactivity theory uses numbers from the information-theoretic (IT) approach to provide a precise explanation of molecular acidity from an altogether new perspective [102].

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Amphotericin B exhibits antimycotic activity against various infections, mainly systemic mycotic infections, Visceral Leishmaniasis, and protozoal infections. Its framework is made up of glycone and aglycone components. The hydrophobic polyene part, hydrophilic polyhydroxy portion, and carboxyl modification site for subsequent modification are all present in the aglycone component. An amine modification site is present in the glycone component for future transformation. Its amphipathic nature causes it to assemble in a hydrous environment. The toxicity generally arises due to dimer formation. It acts by attaching to the ergosterol of fungal cells, responsible for leaking ions from the fungal cell membrane, leading to death. It also binds to cholesterol which is responsible for renal toxicity. It is generally not affected by common drug-resistant mechanisms like drug efflux pumps because it does not bind to the protein as other drugs, but it binds to the ergosterol [44]. The various formulation of AmB is available, as mentioned above, but all those have their limitations. In this article, we have discussed the detail of advancement in its research related to chemical modification and drug delivery approaches as reported by many authors.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: Many authors have reported their efforts to resolve the problem associated with Amphotericin B, and there is a need for a better outcome of the problem and finally for the permanent oral formulation of Amphotericin B as it is available in the intravenous formulation. Also, it is costly & uneasy for administration purposes.
